description: From Middle English merke, mirke, from Old English mirce, myrce (“dark, gloomy, evil”) and Old Norse myrkr (“dark, murky”), both from Proto-Germanic *merkuz (“dark”), from Proto-Indo-European *mergʷ- (“to flicker; to darken; to be dark”). Cognate Danish mørk (“dark”), Norwegian mørk (“dark”), Swedish mörk (“dark”), Icelandic myrkur (“dark”), as also Albanian murg (“dark”), Proto-Slavic *morkъ (“darkness”), Lithuanian márgas (“multicolored”), Ancient Greek ἀμορβός (amorbós, “dark”).

examples: He cannot see through the mantle murk.

description: From Middle English mirke, merke, from Old English mirce, myrce (“darkness, gloom”) and Old Norse myrkr (“darkness, gloom”), both from Proto-Germanic *merkwą, *mirkwiz (“darkness”), Proto-Indo-European *mergʷ- (“to flicker; to darken; to be dark”).

entries.meaning: Darkness, or a dark or gloomy environment.

description: From Middle English mirken, probably from Old Norse myrkja, myrkva (“to make dark, darken”), from Proto-Germanic *mirkwijaną, *mirkwajaną (“to make dark”), from Proto-Indo-European *mergʷ- (“to flicker; to darken; to be dark”).

verbs.description: murk (third-person singular simple present murks, present participle murking, simple past and past participle murked)

entries.meaning: To make murky or be murky; to cloud or obscure, or to be clouded or obscured.
examples: Dawn had been murking through the smoky windows, growing stronger for half an hour...

description: Possibly an alteration of merc, from clipping of mercenary.

verbs.description: murk (third-person singular simple present murks, present participle murking, simple past and past participle murked)

entries.meaning: (African-American Vernacular, MLE) To murder or seriously injure.
examples: cause we be murkin from the boogieAnd shittin on the crowds'cause they jive fakin woody.
